origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Martha Cook building.

did.unittitle: Martha Cook Building (University of Michigan) records 1914-1981 2013-2014
did.abstract: The records of the Martha Cook Building at the University of Michigan (women's dormitory) contains administrative files and historical information about the construction of the building.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group has been donated by the Board of Governors of the Martha Cook Building in several accessions (Donor # 5887) in several accessions.

accessrestrict.p: University records are public records and once fully processed are generally open to research use. Records that contain personally identifiable information will be restricted to protect individual privacy. The restriction of university records is subject to compliance with applicable laws.

The following are terms of restriction for specific genres of records found in this record group:
student records are restricted for fifty years from date of creation.
The record group University of Michigan Martha Cook Building contains 2 folders of restricted student related files covered by FERPA; these files have been removed to the vault.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Board of Governors of the Martha Cook Building.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Martha Cook Building (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Martha Cook Building opened in the fall of 1915 as the second all-women's dormitory on the University of Michigan campus. It was a gift of Mr. William Wilson Cook, a lawyer-philanthropist from New York City who was born and raised in Hillsdale, Michigan. He graduated from the University of Michigan with A.B. and L.L.B. degrees before going on to work in Toledo and then New York City. He became a prominent lawyer and later wrote several books. The last years of Mr. Cook's life were spent studying, reading, writing, and supervising his building projects at the university, including the Martha Cook Building and the Law Quadrangle.

William Cook named the dormitory after his mother, Martha Wolford Cook. As her husband was often away, Martha Cook had the primary responsibility of raising their nine children, William being the third oldest. Mr. Cook was obviously inspired by his mother. The home he built for female students in her memory was intended to provide a unique atmosphere in which "the charm and grace and principles of cultured American womanhood" (Macklin and Chamberlain The Martha Cook Building, p. 4) would be developed. He felt that intellect was important, but he valued character and womanly grace above it.

The building itself was said to be the finest of its type in the nation at the time it was built. Various styles are represented throughout the building, ranging from the Gothic exterior to interiors from Early Renaissance and Tudor Gothic to furnishings from Jacobean and later periods. In one room hangs a life-size portrait of Martha Wolford Cook, which was intended "to portray an epoch in which the mother was queen in her home, respected for the simplicity of her manners and the greatness of her virtues" (ibid., 6). Furniture and accessories include Chinese pottery, sixteenth century Italian sofas, Jacobean chairs, oak tables, a replica of the Venus de Milo carved in Italy from Carrara marble, and a specially-designed Steinway piano inlaid with Circassian walnut. A statue of Portia stands over the front door.

Originally, residency in MCB was offered to senior women only. Eventually, other upperclassmen, graduate students, and freshmen were allowed to live there as well. Because there was often a lengthy waiting list, applicants were assigned points, in part based on their year in school and their grades, and were required to provide a biographical sketch of themselves. The point totals and sketches were used to determine who filled any vacancies that occurred. Over the years a number of Martha Cook Building traditions have developed, including a special dinner for new women in the fall, Friday afternoon tea, a "Messiah Dinner" near Christmas, the Christmas Breakfast, and a Senior Dinner.

Much of the historical sketch above was taken from The Martha Cook Building, by Wystan Stevens, 1976, and The Martha Cook Building, by Elaine Macklin and Tenney Chamberlain, 1970. Copies of both publications may be found in Box 8, under Histories.

scopecontent.p: The records of the first accession span the years 1913 to 1972 and are arranged in the order in which they were received. They cover a broad spectrum of subjects and include substantive records in the Board of Governors, William W. Cook, and the building itself. The first accession contains the following series: Board of Governors Files, Correspondence, Papers, Administrative Records, Reports, Activity Files, and Visual Materials.
Records received in the 1993 accession span the years 1915 to 1990 but are primarily from 1973 to 1979 when Olive Chernow was director of the building.

scopecontent.p: The PAPERS series (1 linear foot 1913-1972), arranged by date received, contains files on the construction of the building, including correspondence with the architects, and specifications and blueprints. It also contains papers related to receptions, petitions for house offices, room lists, and miscellaneous papers and correspondence.

odd.p: (concerning gift of a residential hall to the University of Michigan by William W. Cook, and a list of Board of Governors at Martha Cook Building).

did.unittitle: Meeting 1937 of Resolutions Committee, Student Board and Board of Governors
List of books sent to Martha Cook Building 1916
Alumnae replies to Victory Reunion Invitation 1946
Fiftieth Anniversary of the Martha Cook Building 1965

scopecontent.p: The BOARD OF GOVERNORS series (.25 linear feet, 1930-1973), arranged chronologically, consists of meeting minutes.

The CORRESPONDENCE series (.5 linear feet, 1914-1968), arranged thematically, contains the Board of Governors correspondence, correspondence of the Business Office, miscellaneous correspondence, and the William W. Cook files containing both correspondence and news clippings from 1914 to 1930. Although contained in its own series, various types of correspondence are scattered throughout the accession.

did.unittitle: Correspondence with the University of Michigan
Correspondence 1915-1920 of Mr. & Mrs. Chauncey F. Cook
Correspondence with members of the Board of Governors

scopecontent.p: The ADMINISTRATIVE RECORDS (1 linear foot, 1915-1966) consists of financial statements, social directors' notebooks, house director's notebooks, and the president and vice presidents' reports.

The REPORTS series (.5 linear feet, 1931-1965), arranged thematically, consist of the secretary's reports, treasurer's reports, and activity reports. These include summaries of their activities during the year, as well as their opinions as to the success of various events.
The ACTIVITY FILES series (.75 linear feet, 1934-70), arranged alphabetically, documents dormitory events from 1934 to 1970. Some documented events were held annually, others only once.

The VISUAL MATERIALS series (2 linear feet, undated), arranged alphabetically, includes negatives, photographs (mostly black and white), and prints of furnishings, architecture, people and activities. The negatives are from 1965, but the majority of photographs are undated. In addition, there is VHS tape of the 75th anniversary celebration in 1990, and a scrapbook pertaining to William Wilson Cook's financial and building donations to the university.

did.unittitle: Negatives by U-M News Service October 1965

odd.p: (includes gardens of Martha Cook Building and Condon House; see na 9283)

scopecontent.p: The CHRONOLOGICAL FILES series (.25 linear feet, 1969-1980), arranged chronologically, is comprised of various correspondence, social calendars, activity reports, and other miscellanea from 1969 to 1980. Although not complete in their coverage of any given year's activities, they provide an interesting look at the various events that took place in the Martha Cook Building.

The MINUTES OF THE HOUSE BOARD series (.25 linear feet, 1963-1981), arranged chronologically, documents the meetings held by the House Board, which is composed of residents. The minutes provide an inside look at life in the dormitory, including the daily concerns of residents, rules and regulations, and preparations for social activities.

The TOPICAL FILES series (.5 linear feet, 1915-1990), arranged alphabetically consists of documentation on the duties of the director and other staff, including a procedures manual, a daily activity log, correspondence, a social activities log, and purchasing and maintenance records. Within the miscellaneous folder there is a particularly interesting account of the architecture and furnishings of the Martha Cook Building.
